headline: ‘The Five’ on ‘woke’ school boards, crime in US
subHeadline: Dana Perino, Greg Gutfeld, Dagen McDowell, Richard Fowler, Jesse Watters

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Waters along with Dagen McDowell, Richard Fowler, Dana Perino and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5:00 in New York City and this is THE FIVE. It's a result against the left's radical identity politics agenda all across the country. Remember that New Jersey school district that yanked all holiday names off the calendar just to avoid hurt feelings? Well, they just reversed course. Concerned parents say they are being smeared as "right wing fanatics" after calling out the school board.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: You brought shame and notoriety upon our idyllic town. So after you overturn this idiotic decision, you will resign. All of you will resign today.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: You managed to wake up the entire community of Randolph. This is a flash point. We draw the line in the sand. You have overreached.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: In Lowden County, Virginia, the epicenter of the push back against critical race theory, the school board there is meeting for the final time this year tonight. Parents telling school officials they won't be silenced.

utterances.speaker: IAN PRIOR, FIGHT FOR SCHOOLS PAC
utterances.sentences: This is about a parents' movement to take back our schools. To get a seat at the table with how our schools are run. You have special interests. You have activists. That's the only group they seem to listen to, whereas parents show up every day to try and make their voices heard and we get ignored.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And in Colorado, a mayor there tried to suspend the Pledge of Allegiance at school board meetings due to unspecified reasons, but attendees rescinded it anyway.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Due to direct and indirect threats, inappropriate comments and how to public meetings, the general divisiveness this is creating in our community, we will not be doing the Pledge of Allegiance during town of Silverton board of trustee meetings.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: But it's just been done for a long time (inaudible) all took an oath. And we as a board collectively decided it would be done.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: This is not up for discussion at this moment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, not up for discussion, Dana. Do you really think it was divisive, the pledge, maybe one person said they didn't like it?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. Maybe like a tweet --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- a tweet and there's a panic. When everybody attending the meeting stands up and says the pledge anyway, at the end, that guy, the moderator, he says, that's out of order. I think that we're showing examples all across America, first of all, of what it's like to actually attend a school board meeting. I was talking to a guy the other day, he was at one of the Randolph meetings. He said, never go to school board meeting in my life, and now they've gone to several of them and you see American parents all across the country saying, wait, what's going on in my school district and showing up at school board meetings, which is actually, I think very healthy. You want people to be more energized, engaged, and possibly you'll see somebody, you know, like Ian Prior. I'm not speaking for him. I don't know. But you could imagine that because he is awoke in this movement in Lowden County, Virginia, perhaps he'll run for school board. You always like ask yourself, like, well, would you want to run? Would you want to run? And actually getting into the arena is one of the important things. The average American is more patriotic, more moderate, more -- I mean, much less partisan than any media conversation would have you think.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: And that's where the action is, Greg, school board meetings.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, look. I'm a little pessimistic. I think it's too late. I mean, these are -- we have three examples here. When you have three examples, you have a segment. Right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's like if there were two we wouldn't have done this but we had three and I applaud it, and these people are brave but I think it's too late. I think the indoctrination is present in our culture, our entertainment industry, academia, and also, our corporations. Have you seen a typical H.R. e-mail lately? We won't mention it but the language is directly lifted from academic identity politics' lexicon. It is everywhere you look. I don't think I have seen anything spread so fast in my life and it preys upon these two -- the two flaws of human nature. One of them is fear. People are terrified of being ostracized, or losing their jobs or both, which is why you see students parroting this woke babble from their teachers and you see corporate execs embracing the diversity platitudes, and why entertainers are so desperately waving the BLM flag. It's because they would rather you not look in their past for any sexual indiscretions. That's fear. But the other thing is that fear causes people to blend in, right? This is why human beings imitate each other's behavior. They don't want to stand out. That was the whole -- that was a method for survival. So, if you don't want the woke after you, then you parrot the woke, right? Its memetic camouflage. So that's why I believe that this stuff is spreading, and I don't know how to stop it because fear and just wanting to belong is letting it happen and it's happening all around us. That's why these things are into -- I'm glad they are there at the school board and maybe that's where the fight has to happen because it's visual and people will be persuaded by it. But I think about like, are we going to have a fight with our corporate H.R.? No. Are people going to fight at the principals at their schools -- well, I guess they are -- the colleges? Are they going to go after -- I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I for one think our H.R. department does a bang up job.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was using it as a generic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm kidding.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A generic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Did I do -- I think you're right about corporate America.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: They have surrendered to the woke people, but I disagree on the school board front, Dagen. I think parents are very outraged and they are not going to put up with it anymore and that's where they are getting traction and that's why we're showing this.

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.sentences: And that's where the change begins to happen because the people who are working in H.R. at these major corporations who are making marketing decisions purely for the fringed left, they were indoctrinated through college and that's who is working in these corporation now. So if you start, you know, even the grade school level, the high school level. But to Dana's point, most Americans are go along get along kind of folks who really try to avoid controversy. They work their asses off. They are dealing with their families and their friends and church, and maybe they want to go fishing once every few months. They really don't have time for this nonsense. But all it takes is one small group of trifling sanctimonious jerks to set them off. And I call it the reverse domino theory. So instead of falling down one by one, you have one -- it just takes one person to stand up, one outraged parent (ph), one -- or citizen speaking up and then 10 more will stand up because they feel supported and they get loud, and that's how change happens. And this is not -- they are trying to paint it like these are conservative parents and conservative individuals. No way. You start to look at who's a lot of these people are. They are across the spectrum of races and socioeconomic groups, but they see their children being indoctrinating into hate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's like you're talking about an educational tea party.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Grassroots.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's where the action is. Richard, I assume you agree with everything that we just said.

utterances.speaker: RICHARD FOWLER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.sentences: Listen, I spent my afternoon reading some of these critical race theory bills because I think you got reading is fundamental.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I've never heard of that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow, interesting.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: And you know what, I was dismayed because not only are these bills poorly worded and vague in their writing but some of these bills make literally no sense, right. One, the bill in Iowa bans the teaching, and I wrote it down. It bans the teaching of the following topics, sexism, slavery, racial segregation --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, it's in the bill. Did you read it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is not true.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Did you read it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I haven't read the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Okay then. Then you --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And I would that -- no, I will tell you something. I will bet --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Then you don't know. Then you don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- you cannot find anything in the bill that says we will not teach slavery in school in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: It says it's prohibited. It says it's prohibited from the curriculum.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I guarantee. I guarantee you, Richard --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: It's prohibited from the curriculum. It's in section five of the bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- they have not prohibited the teaching of slavery in history class in the state of Iowa.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, allow me to finish.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I guarantee that's wrong.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Allow me to finish.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And I say that with no knowledge of the bill. No knowledge of the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Okay. Well, therein lies your problem.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because if that actually was in the bill, it would have been on the front page of every newspaper in this country.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, it actually was in Iowa, but back to what I was saying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Johnny, time to go.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: So the topics it currently blocks is sexism, slavery, racial segregation, racial discrimination including topics related to the enactment and the enforcement of laws resulting in sexism, racial oppression and segregation. That's like half of American history.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, so you're saying history is banned.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: So back in history -- excuse me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: History is banned in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: So what that actually means is if you're a student, a high school student in Iowa and you're studying for the American AP history exam --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: -- you're likely to fail because half of these topics won't be taught. So, good luck to the students in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Okay. So they're just going to skip over --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: And the bill in Oklahoma.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Basically from 1776, they're not teaching --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: And the bill in Tennessee

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, after they can't teach -- they can't -- and actually --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- history, sports, in 1965 in Iowa. I don't believe that, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Actually, if you read the wording specific, they really couldn't teach 1976 because Abigail Adams' letters to her husband about remembering the women would actually be illegal, part of the bill in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, that's what I've said. They don't even start in 1776.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I was just telling you what the bill says which is part of the problem --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: History starts in Iowa in 1965 --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: -- which is part of the problem, because when you attack critical race theory and actually not talk about what's actually being taught in class which is the truth about American history we have this dilemma which is vaguely, poorly written, quickly written bills, that makes absolutely positively no sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We will find out the truth about the bill in Iowa and then we will tell you as soon as we find out.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Have fun reading them. I did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Coming up next, a bloody crime wave has the public terrified. And Biden's plan to fix it is to blame the last administration.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: President Biden forced to confront a nationwide spike in violent crime but it looks to be too little too late. Disturbing new video from Detroit shows an 11-year-old boy, his father, and a third passenger, being shot while sitting in a car. In New York City, a campaign volunteer was stabbed multiple times with an icepick. The president is set to finally address the carnage tomorrow but instead of focusing on restoring law and order, Biden will blame guns and the last administration.

utterances.speaker: JEN PSAKI, WHITE HOUSE PRESS CONFERENCE
utterances.sentences: There are major cities across the country where gun violence is absolutely the driver, where it is absolutely increasing and that will be a central part of what he'll talk about when he delivers his remarks tomorrow. There has been, one, an increase in violent crime over the last 18 months. It's not just over the last few months. And actually if you look statistically back, it's more over the last five years or so.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: And a former Obama appointee says police are responsible for the violence.

utterances.speaker: BRITTANY PACKNETT, ACTIVIST
utterances.sentences: There are a lot of police unions and GOP operatives that would like for us to believe that this recent crime wave has everything to do with this idea of defunding the police. Rising crime is not the fault of the movement. It's actually the fault of the police and this has been our point all along. Why should we keep funding systems and institutions that keep rendering themselves ineffective?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Greg, the Biden administration is clearly concerned that the spike in violence is going to hurt them and their standing in the polls.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know, gun violence isn't any more relevant than icepick violence, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's like, why don't we start talking about icepick violence because these are inanimate objects. It's interesting watching how the media and the democrats change the language so that it absolves the criminals. So what they are doing now is they're including gang shootings and routine gun crime that's been around as mass shootings, which mass shootings were always about these planned rampages, right? Now it's just every day, like CNN will say there were eight mass shootings this week and you go, wow, I didn't hear of any of them. And then you look at them, it's like, oh, you know, that's gang stuff. The problem with this stuff when they keep saying gun violence, and this is where their whole theory falls apart. The guns existed before and after this dramatic spike. So, it's not just gun violence. It's actually the perpetrators, a rise in perpetrators. A rise in violence. The gun is simply a tool. And when you explain these statistics plainly to the media, their response is after you saw what, I think with Stelter, Brian Stelter a few days ago, rather than acknowledge the spike in crime, the issue becomes are you blowing the spike in crime out of proportion? So whenever the media is found to be wrong on something, rather than admit it, they look at you and you go, but you're pouncing on it. You're blowing this out of proportion. Yes, yes, yes. I mean, there was crime -- there's crime, but you're blowing it out of proportion because the media cannot report on crime because it illustrates the failure of the far left policies that they have been pushing for decades and recently embraced in the last few years through the BLM movement. All of this stuff is falling apart before their eyes. And they'd rather see a country suffer than admit they were wrong and back the right course.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I was just thinking about President Biden having this event tomorrow. We talked yesterday about the polling numbers showing that crime and the issue of immigration are the two issues that are weighing down his approval ratings even though he is still up 52 percent where he had been at 57 or 58 percent. So, I think one of the reason they're having this event tomorrow is they know that they've got an issue so they're trying to shore themselves up politically. But if you remember, it was -- President Biden, when he was senator and the Clintons before him, their support of the 1994 Crime Bill was what the progressive left was hanging on their necks as an albatross. It was going to make it very hard for them to be able to get the votes of the left wing of the party. And so now, if they go forward tomorrow and they say, well now we're going to get tough on crime, I don't think he's going to say that. He would be, you know, called a traitor by the left and no one on the right would take him seriously.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: And he's going to talk about guns. And in New York City, you've seen all of the crimes that are up this year are murder, rape, felony assault, grand theft auto, housing crimes, other sex crimes, shooting victims, shooting incidents and hate crimes, but this is a city where the second amendment doesn't exist, Richard. So, how can you marry the two? Because he's going to talk about essentially hammering down law-abiding gun owners, not getting guns out of the hands of criminals because, again, they coddle criminals and they treat victims like garbage.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, a couple of things on that particular point. Number one, as a licensed gun owner myself, I don't think this is about taking the guns out of the hands of people like myself, but I think it's making sure that most of the crimes that we see happening that are gun crimes are because of folks have illegal guns. And I think we have to acknowledge that America is country that has poor supporters. So, if you have bad gun laws, say for example, in a bordering state, you can go over there, you can buy a gun and you can drive it across the border, right? And many of the guns that we see and many of the mass shootings that we see happening in this country sometimes happen because of illegal guns. In the city of Chicago, right, this past weekend was one of the most horrific weekends there and most of those crimes were committed because of illegal guns. Not purchased in the city of Chicago because you can't purchase a gun in the city of Chicago. They are purchased in Indiana and in other parts of the country that have terrible gun laws. So what Joe Biden is going to do tomorrow is say, hey, look, we've got to do something. Thoughts and prayers around the fact that we have a surge in gun violence in this country is not enough. Since the beginning of the year, we've had 283 mass shootings in this country. That's a 40 percent increase since last year and a 65 percent increase since 2019. So something has got to be done, right. And it can't just be --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You illustrated my point by saying mass shootings. You say these are all the -- what are these mass shootings?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: A mass shooting is any time more than three or more people are killed by a gun. And sadly, in the city of Chicago, it happens all the time and it's happening because of illegal guns.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's called -- that's gang violence.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Sure. Call it -- call it a gang violence, but even the police think that there's a problem with illegal guns.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But when you change it to mass shootings, you're blaming everything together so you can talk about the gun when you should be talking about the gangs and the criminals that are being let in and let out.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But even -- but (inaudible), even if you support police, even if you support police, if you talk to the police chiefs all across the country they will tell you one of the number one problems they face is the proliferation of illegal guns on their streets. So police agree that we've got to do something about the fact --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And also criminals going out and those guns somehow ending up back in their hands.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: This has been --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Sure. But why don't we get these guns off the streets to begin with by passing laws and make it harder for folks to get guns. Period.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: I want to hear Joe Biden talk about all the crimes outside of the gun crimes like elderly people getting punched in the face by somebody who has been arrested 20 times in the last couple of years. Why is that person on the street? I want to talk about just the quality of life crimes which are totally illegal here in New York City, so little children are walking down the street and having to witness sex acts in broad daylight, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm glad Richard --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That wasn't Jesse's fault.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I'm glad Richard is concerned about the poorest borders, just borders between states, not between countries. I'm glad you're consistent.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: No, let's not mix -- oh boy, here we go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Johnny has been hard at work looking at the Iowa bill. And Johnny reports the word slavery is not even in the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Listen, I read the bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: According to Johnny, they want to ban the 1619 Project --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: The 1619 project is not in the bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- which incorporates slavery --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: The 1619 Project --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- but they do not want to ban the teaching of slavery.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Listen, you can read an article, but I've actually read all of the bills.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's what we're reporting from the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: You can control fine because listen, let's be very clear.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We're not talking about this anymore. I just reported what was not in the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: You can't read a 10-page bill on a commercial break to be fair and to be clear. I read the bills --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You find if, until the audience -- you find it --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I already did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You spent the entire commercial break looking at your phone trying to find it.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: No, you sat the entire commercial break --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And you spent more minutes during the segment, trying to find it and you still haven't found it. Let me talk about something else.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: You, listen, Jesse, deal. Deal. Deal.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'd let him talk.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: You and your producer spent the whole commercial break trying to read a bill that's (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I want to talk about something else. You still haven't actually pointed to the tact (ph).

utterances.speaker: MCDWOELL
utterances.sentences: I want to hear what he has to say.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Let me just go full Gutfeld for a second, and going full Gutfeld that means you blame the media for everything. The mainstream media is lying about why black Americans are dying. The mainstream media back to defund the police movement. It gave license to these radical city councils to actually to defund the police. It triggers a crime wave. Black Americans got slaughtered in the streets and then you deny there was a crime wave. Now all of a sudden they are waking up to the fact that there is a crime wave and they're heaping praise on Joe Biden for tackling the crime wave they help to create. The "Washington Post," because you know I read these briefing materials for these segments very carefully, they actually did a whole story on this. They quoted an aid to Michael Dukakis. Michael Dukakis said there is nothing the federal government can do about crime because it's a local issue. It's the same Michael Dukakis that got rocked by 41 by being soft on crime. Then they quoted three anti-police activists in the article. No balance at all, and it leads the reader to believe it's the fault of the Republicans for the rise in crime because blah, blah, blah, NRA. They didn't spend one minute interviewing a black crime victim. They didn't interview any family members who had their family members shot. They didn't interview anybody scared that's living in the inner-city that is afraid to go to school. All they care about is the political effects on the Democrats and if it's risky or if it's safe for the Democrats. No, no, no. This is about life and death in the inner-city and the media doesn't care about it.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: They will focus group and poll the subject to death while there is actual deaths in the streets.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Ahead, some serious media bias. The "Washington Post" giving Democrats cover after a major flip-flop.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The "Washington Post" getting slammed over a report on Democrats changing stance on voter I.D. laws. The headline reading this, "Stacey Abrams and the Democrats' Evolution on Voter I.D." The former gubernatorial candidate now says she could back voter I.D. which comes just two months after she compared the requirements to Jim Crow. Other Democrats have been bashing Republican-backed voting laws.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY)
utterances.sentences: Making it harder for younger, poorer, non-white and typically Democratic voters to have -- to access the ballot. Shame, shame, shame.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MAZIE HIRONO (D-HI)
utterances.sentences: This is why when the states start to enact these kinds of voter suppression laws, what I call steal your vote laws.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT)
utterances.sentences: -- is to try to deny people of color, young people, poor people the right to vote, people with disabilities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, when Senator Manchin of West Virginia came out, Greg, with his compromise bill. He said, here we go. I'll have voter ID. And Stacey Abrams from Georgia said, I like it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But she has this Web site called Jim Crow 2.0 and she still lists voter ID, that provision as voter suppression.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I think that -- this is what happens when you overplay the race card because what happens is, there's no workable solution. Like if you constantly keep saying everything is racist, there's nothing left. They don't -- they're not even sure -- the Democrat Party isn't even sure what they're talking about. Years from now, people are going to look back at this era, especially what Chuck Schumer did in the Democratic Party as the real racist, the white liberal supremacist for assuming that blacks can't get an ID. Think about the contradiction between that message and the message of diversity which is positive. Hey, black people, you can be an astronaut, you can be an engineer, you can be a rocket scientist, but you can't get an ID, because that's beyond your abilities. It is the same -- it's the same mentality that is behind critical race theory which is white supremacy for liberal elites. It's an academic restatement that blacks aren't capable and only superior whites, superior whites to blacks can help them. That is why it is so disgusting.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: A couple of the other issues that are in this bill are provisions, Dagen, include a proposal to divert taxpayer money to pay for campaigns. That's really, really unpopular. And then, also a mandate for ballot trafficking, which basically says you can go around and pick up the bills - - or pick up the ballots and take them to your local precinct.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: They're federalizing election law and they're taking power away from the states. And I think everybody should be upset about that. And to kind of paraphrase something that Senator Tom Cotton said, he said, the Democrats, if you listen to those comments, they're not defending their own H.R.1 or the voting bill. They're attacking Republicans because they know that they can't stand on the merits of this bill. And I do love -- it's what Greg was talking about in the last -- in the last segment, but I do love how democrats evolve and soften their positions in the words of the media, but Republicans cave and flip flop. Because that's how -- that's how they frame it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's -- those are verbs that they use. Richard, the Honest Elections Project, they did a poll on this bill. And it turns out that only 29 percent of people actually have any idea what's in it.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Listen, people don't read bills.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Stop right there.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But I do think what's interesting is in the Joe -- in the -- in the Joe Manchin compromise, right, which is the first amendment that would be taken up if there was allowed to be a debate, which there won't because Republicans will block it, is actually some things that I think are bipartisan in nature, which is what Joe Biden committed to being, right? He said, the Republicans' biggest sticking point was voter ID. Democrats said we're willing to give on voter ID in exchange for expanding -- expansions of early voting, banning partisan redistricting, which I think everybody agrees with. If you're a Republican in New York, you probably are against partisan redistricting. Or if you're a Republican in Illinois, you're probably against partisan redistricting, right? And also making Election Day holiday, which I think most folks agree with. If you can make Election Day holiday, everybody will have the ability to vote.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Another holiday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I'm all for it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And we have to work.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: We will always -- we work because we were in the media.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We'll tape a holiday special, fan mail.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But I do think that this is what you call meeting in the middle, right? There is -- there's a lot of provisions in the Joe -- in the Joe Manchin compromised of what was in the 1965 civil rights -- Voting Rights Act, bring in those across in exchange for voter ID which something that Republicans have been asking for very long time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But I mean, Jesse, there were a couple of issues I just mentioned, taxpayer money for campaigns, ballot trafficking, and a few others.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's not a compromise. It's called a poison pill. Fox News Alert, I was right. Richard was wrong.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: The definitive answer is that Iowa Republicans did not, I repeat, did not submit a bill banning the teaching of slavery in schools in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Where did they ban the teaching of slavery? Where did they -- did they not ban the teaching of slavery?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Fox News Alert, it's over.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Did they not ban the teaching of slavery?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: This was about some curriculum involving --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Did they not ban -- they ban the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- diversity training in companies. That was wrong. I was right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Excuse me. So, the bill --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I was right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: -- to be clear and to be fair --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Go ahead, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: The bill bans the teaching, and let me go back to my notes, of slavery, sexism, racial segregation, and racial discrimination --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Where, Richard? Where, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: In training for employees and students --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, OK, so not in schools.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: In a school setting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Where else would they be --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's not what you said. That's not what you said, Richard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's the funniest thing ever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Teaching slavery is not prohibited in Iowa in this bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Not to mention the fact -- not to mention the fact that the bill is poor -- it's poorly written, it is vague --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Poorly read too.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: It has no -- it has no enforcement criteria, and it bans the ideal of teaching slavery and --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Just take the shake.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Just take the L.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: There's none to be taken.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Just take the L, Richard. I'm extending a hand.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: We'll shake, but there's no -- the fact is that it's a poorly written bill and you know it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Listen, all bills are poorly written. I agree with that.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: You should read them more.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: We're killing it -- we're killing it with the Iowa demo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right, up next, shameful and grifty, a former Obama ethics chief plays into hunter Biden's art career.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There reviews are in for Hunter's art career. Former Obama White House ethics chief is tearing into the First Son's plan to sell his paintings for prices up to a half million. That's one of them. "The notion of a president son capitalizing on that relationship by selling art at obviously inflated prices and keeping the public in the dark about who's funneling money to him has a shameful and grifty feel to it." And Hunter is not the only member -- family member cashing in. Relatives of key White House officials have landed jobs in the administration. But Jen Psaki says there's nothing to worry about.

utterances.speaker: JEN PSAKI, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.sentences: We have the highest ethical standards of any administration in history. A number of ethics officials have conveyed that and we're proud of that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, could you argue that Hunter's paintings are designed to keep his nose clean. Because that's why he uses straws, he get paint in it and they can't put it up your nose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I mean, that could be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It might be a part of you know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's how you beat your habit, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I loved doing blow art.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I did as a kid. That was one of the best things that Vacation Bible School we would do that. It's fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Vacation Bible School.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What's vacation Bible School?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I went to Vacation Bible School.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You went to --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: I do too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wait, wait, wait --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We're the weirdos here, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We didn't go to the Vacation Bible School.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, in the summertime, it's sometimes Christmas holiday or Easter holiday --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Yes, I went to VBS.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- there's a week where you go to like a camp every day. It's Vacation Bible School. And you get to do like crafts and activities like blow art.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: And learn about Jesus.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: And learn the Beatitudes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Maybe we should have gone to that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think -- I think there's a hole in my life.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Vacation Bible School was awesome. The last thing I'll say on this is responding indignantly to questions about ethics in regards to the President's son or, you know, other situations, is kind of ironic given that they really ran against President Trump based on his ethics --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: -- and their perceived view of ethics.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: How quickly they forget, Dana. How quickly they forgot. Dagen, you know, what's wrong with selling art based on your notoriety? It's not just kind of like an autograph?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: No. If your father is in the White House and you have a history of questionable at the very least behavior. A year and a half ago, nobody even knew this loser was an artist until the New York Times wrote this glowing profile of him just as the pandemic was taking off, but they won't appeal it for the Coronavirus coverage. There's a new artist in town, the name is Biden was the title of it. And they talk about oh the paint-stained forearms and fingers and the black and red deep under his nails. So, now he's selling these things are trying to for half a million dollars. I'd say that -- of that price, 90 percent is bribery, maybe 10 percent is for the paint, but nobody now is going to buy this dreck because they're going to have their background looked into. Like, you're going to get a ring-a-ding-ding from the FBI or Justice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, maybe he slips coke into the canvas. That's a great way to get it over the porous border. Richard, the one thing about nepotism, I think that we could agree on, is that it hurts minorities because we have - - you're already laughing at my question?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: How did minority get into this?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Because white people have the jobs that they can just hire their cronies' kids.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I thought we're talking about Hunter Biden?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, we're talking about nepotism.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Well, listen, I --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Minorities are hurt most by nepotism because they aren't in the power structure to give the jobs to their kids and friends.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Fair, fair enough.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think that's in the bill in the Iowa bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Fair enough. Look, I think that -- you know, I don't think the Hunter should be selling his paintings. And listen, I also think that in this particular one, as we talked about Hunter Biden, it's worth pointing out that there's still a pending justice investigation that is going unharmed, untouched by the Merrick Garland Justice Department against Hunter Biden, which speaks to the fact that this -- that Joe Biden, he believes in this ideal of an independent justice system and a Justice Department and that's -- and that's happening. With that being said, it's also worth pointing out that there's no Biden people that work in the White House unlike the Trump White House where everybody who work --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: But their point was that though, that there are -- there are few people who are couples that are appointed in the White House.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That often happens. You meet in Washington and you stay in Washington, you know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's the swamp, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Nobody wanted to hire Peter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: When I coined the phrase swamp, that's what I was talking about. We need to drain that swamp. Jesse, I don't know if selling art is a bad thing because I have a feeling you and I are going to be doing this very -- in the next 10 years.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: We're going to be doing blow art?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, or blow art, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Or Vacation Bible School.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We should probably do both.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: One before the other. So, do you consider me a petty person, Gutfeld?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Perhaps.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Would you mind if I acted a little petty?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, please do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Last week, I said on this very show that Hunter selling his little blow art to, I don't know, a Russian billionaire for a half a mil was violating the spirit of campaign finance and potential, I don't know, laundering laws, bribery statutes, whatever. Now, did that make waves? No. Then the ethics expert for Joe Biden says it and everyone goes, oh, really? Well, perhaps we should look into this. It doesn't take an expert to realize this is a scam.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Do I need a new title?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Is Fox Host not enough for people to pay attention?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: You need to be an ethics expert.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, do I have to do law school for people to listen to me? It's clearly a scam. Why does an expert have to tell you, and then everybody says, oh yeah, it's a scam? I said it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: When you look at -- look at those paintings. Just look at those paintings you realize that it looks like, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: I don't know why you'd spend $1 million on that though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What does it look like to you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Well, I was waiting for him to throw one up there, but it just looks like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What does that -- like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It looks like a leftover from a smurf orgy.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: But why would you spend $1 million on that? I just don't understand.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, well, that's what it is. It's --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: That's the point, Richard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, you don't understand, Richard.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: It's influence meddling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, "THE FASTEST" is up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We got time for "THE FASTEST."

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Welcome back. It's time for "THE FASTEST." Researchers are coming up with a special straw device that will -- that promises to cure the hiccups 90 percent of the time. It will cost about $14.00. So, Dagen, would you buy it?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: No, I like being frightened --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I was going to say the opposite. I hate it.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: To cure -- to cure -- like, if you come up just a little -- if you come up behind me and make the sound of the doll from trilogy of terror, like that will cure hiccups anytime. And I actually enjoyed that.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Jesse?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Classic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Hiccups are for drunks and babies. I don't think researchers should be focused on this. I'd like to cure cancer. We could focus on hiccups later.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Hiccups is a very serious condition for some people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It is -- well, maybe I shouldn't say that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I read the bill.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I preferred my mom's method which is a teaspoon of sugar. It was apparently supposed to help you -- like, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, that's the medicine goes down.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I know, but -- well, I don't know. That's what she thought would cure hiccups too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Maybe in Bible camp.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You have to try it.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: If one of my kids had hiccups, they'd be out the door.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Would you try the straw though?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Would you buy the straw?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, because you have to weigh the incidence, the number of times you have hiccups versus the cost of carrying a product around. How many times you got the hiccups? Once every two years. I tried to go back through my head the last time I had hiccups, I can't remember. So, you actually don't really need a product unless you're one of these persistent hiccupers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So, you have a purse. You put it in the purse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Purse, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And that's how you carry it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You carry a gun in your purse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know I didn't have a purse, Dana. I carry --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's called man bag.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's a man bag, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's a man bag.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Fanny pack.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Fanny pack.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't have a fanny pack.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: When you're walking Jesse Jr. around the park.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Stop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Do you have a little front bag for your baby?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You mean a baby bjorn?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: A baby bjorn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I have but I haven't rocked it yet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You haven't rocked it? God helped me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I haven't rocked the bjorn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: God help me.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: All right, "ONE MORE THING" is up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's time now for "ONE MORE THING." So, yesterday, I was off. The ratings were particularly good, so that was a little disturbing, but I'm OK with it. I had the honor to play in the 30th annual Van Fleet Memorial Golf Tournament at Baltusrol in New Jersey hosted by the Korea Society. It helps foster good relationship between the United States and Korea. You know, James Van Fleet was the commanding general of the U.S. Army during the Korean War and we're very grateful for him. Also to Mike Woods who co-chaired the event, Big Sun Holdings right there. And special shout out to the boys Friends Academy Lacrosse team won the Long Island State Championship, 15-14 in OT, beat Port Jefferson for the title. Congrats, guys. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: OK, so I read a book this weekend and it was Jesse's book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I have to tell you, I read it in one day. I loved it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Cover to cover, very funny, very smart.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Very well-written. I thought the page-turner. I'm going to -- if it's OK, I'm going to do this something that you did. I am -- John gave me permission to read one of the little mom text thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Oh, OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So, when you get the book and everybody should, you're going to be very tempted not to skip ahead to the end, you're going to skip ahead to the How I Saved My Mom's text chapter. That's the -- that's the sweet stuff, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I appear in this a couple of times a couple.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: A couple.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: This is from your mom. Stop making sweeping and generalizing inaccurate statements about what Democrats are seeking. Note those who won the election on this issue just as reported by Dana. And what Jessie does in these is he responds to his mom and he says, stop citing Dana. It goes on and on. Anyway --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She cites you quite a bit.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: She does cites me quite a bit.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She's very irritated.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Even all the way through to the end of the acknowledgment, I loved it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you very much for the endorsement. I really appreciate that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Congrats.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: In one day, I'm telling you, it's a page-turner. Gutfeld has only gotten through one chapter. Go ahead, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right, tonight on "GUTFELD!" we have for the whole hour of Caitlyn Jenner. It's going to be awesome, Mercedes Schlapp, Kat Timpf, hopefully, Tyrus but he's still at the airport.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Come on, Tyrus.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And there's a giant storm, so it looks like you're going to be sitting in the chair, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: All right. I better get changed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: If he -- if he -- I feel bad for him, but I don't know how he's going to make it in the storm. And I feel bad for him, but then you know what makes me feel good? This. Greg's humans are bad people. Think about this. You're a squirrel and you see some bird feeder and you're hungry and you keep trying to get up there but you just can't do it. But you keep trying because you know it's there. And just gravity says if you climb up, you could do it. Not if the person who owns it has coated the pole with Vaseline. She wanted to stop the squirrel from stealing food out of her bird feeder so she smeared Vaseline on the bird feeder pole making her a bad person. I almost sound like you, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Genius.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Is that genius? Really?

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.sentences: Oh, don't do it --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.sentences: OK. To Greg's point, when humans are bad, this is what happens to them. You try on your -- the shock collar that you bought for your dog, Tilly, but your friend turned it all the way up as high as it would go and what happens. Listen.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.sentences: Men are so smart.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS

utterances.sentences: I've got a cattle prod that your wife can borrow?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: She'll take you up on that. Go ahead, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.sentences: Three friends in Egypt are putting their heads together to create a car that drives on water. Yes, indeed, America. It's true. utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody. I'm Jesse Waters along with Dagen McDowell, Richard Fowler, Dana Perino and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5:00 in New York City and this is THE FIVE. It's a result against the left's radical identity politics agenda all across the country. Remember that New Jersey school district that yanked all holiday names off the calendar just to avoid hurt feelings? Well, they just reversed course. Concerned parents say they are being smeared as "right wing fanatics" after calling out the school board.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: You brought shame and notoriety upon our idyllic town. So after you overturn this idiotic decision, you will resign. All of you will resign today.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: You managed to wake up the entire community of Randolph. This is a flash point. We draw the line in the sand. You have overreached.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: In Lowden County, Virginia, the epicenter of the push back against critical race theory, the school board there is meeting for the final time this year tonight. Parents telling school officials they won't be silenced.

utterances.speaker: IAN PRIOR, FIGHT FOR SCHOOLS PAC
utterances.utterance: This is about a parents' movement to take back our schools. To get a seat at the table with how our schools are run. You have special interests. You have activists. That's the only group they seem to listen to, whereas parents show up every day to try and make their voices heard and we get ignored.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And in Colorado, a mayor there tried to suspend the Pledge of Allegiance at school board meetings due to unspecified reasons, but attendees rescinded it anyway.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: Due to direct and indirect threats, inappropriate comments and how to public meetings, the general divisiveness this is creating in our community, we will not be doing the Pledge of Allegiance during town of Silverton board of trustee meetings.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: But it's just been done for a long time (inaudible) all took an oath. And we as a board collectively decided it would be done.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.utterance: This is not up for discussion at this moment.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, not up for discussion, Dana. Do you really think it was divisive, the pledge, maybe one person said they didn't like it?

utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. Maybe like a tweet --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- a tweet and there's a panic. When everybody attending the meeting stands up and says the pledge anyway, at the end, that guy, the moderator, he says, that's out of order. I think that we're showing examples all across America, first of all, of what it's like to actually attend a school board meeting. I was talking to a guy the other day, he was at one of the Randolph meetings. He said, never go to school board meeting in my life, and now they've gone to several of them and you see American parents all across the country saying, wait, what's going on in my school district and showing up at school board meetings, which is actually, I think very healthy. You want people to be more energized, engaged, and possibly you'll see somebody, you know, like Ian Prior. I'm not speaking for him. I don't know. But you could imagine that because he is awoke in this movement in Lowden County, Virginia, perhaps he'll run for school board. You always like ask yourself, like, well, would you want to run? Would you want to run? And actually getting into the arena is one of the important things. The average American is more patriotic, more moderate, more -- I mean, much less partisan than any media conversation would have you think.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.utterance: And that's where the action is, Greg, school board meetings.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, look. I'm a little pessimistic. I think it's too late. I mean, these are -- we have three examples here. When you have three examples, you have a segment. Right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's like if there were two we wouldn't have done this but we had three and I applaud it, and these people are brave but I think it's too late. I think the indoctrination is present in our culture, our entertainment industry, academia, and also, our corporations. Have you seen a typical H.R. e-mail lately? We won't mention it but the language is directly lifted from academic identity politics' lexicon. It is everywhere you look. I don't think I have seen anything spread so fast in my life and it preys upon these two -- the two flaws of human nature. One of them is fear. People are terrified of being ostracized, or losing their jobs or both, which is why you see students parroting this woke babble from their teachers and you see corporate execs embracing the diversity platitudes, and why entertainers are so desperately waving the BLM flag. It's because they would rather you not look in their past for any sexual indiscretions. That's fear. But the other thing is that fear causes people to blend in, right? This is why human beings imitate each other's behavior. They don't want to stand out. That was the whole -- that was a method for survival. So, if you don't want the woke after you, then you parrot the woke, right? Its memetic camouflage. So that's why I believe that this stuff is spreading, and I don't know how to stop it because fear and just wanting to belong is letting it happen and it's happening all around us. That's why these things are into -- I'm glad they are there at the school board and maybe that's where the fight has to happen because it's visual and people will be persuaded by it. But I think about like, are we going to have a fight with our corporate H.R.? No. Are people going to fight at the principals at their schools -- well, I guess they are -- the colleges? Are they going to go after -- I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I for one think our H.R. department does a bang up job.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was using it as a generic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm kidding.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A generic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Did I do -- I think you're right about corporate America.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They have surrendered to the woke people, but I disagree on the school board front, Dagen. I think parents are very outraged and they are not going to put up with it anymore and that's where they are getting traction and that's why we're showing this.

utterances.speaker: DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: And that's where the change begins to happen because the people who are working in H.R. at these major corporations who are making marketing decisions purely for the fringed left, they were indoctrinated through college and that's who is working in these corporation now. So if you start, you know, even the grade school level, the high school level. But to Dana's point, most Americans are go along get along kind of folks who really try to avoid controversy. They work their asses off. They are dealing with their families and their friends and church, and maybe they want to go fishing once every few months. They really don't have time for this nonsense. But all it takes is one small group of trifling sanctimonious jerks to set them off. And I call it the reverse domino theory. So instead of falling down one by one, you have one -- it just takes one person to stand up, one outraged parent (ph), one -- or citizen speaking up and then 10 more will stand up because they feel supported and they get loud, and that's how change happens. And this is not -- they are trying to paint it like these are conservative parents and conservative individuals. No way. You start to look at who's a lot of these people are. They are across the spectrum of races and socioeconomic groups, but they see their children being indoctrinating into hate.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's like you're talking about an educational tea party.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Grassroots.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's where the action is. Richard, I assume you agree with everything that we just said.

utterances.speaker: RICHARD FOWLER, FOX NEWS CONTRIBUTOR
utterances.utterance: Listen, I spent my afternoon reading some of these critical race theory bills because I think you got reading is fundamental.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I've never heard of that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Wow, interesting.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And you know what, I was dismayed because not only are these bills poorly worded and vague in their writing but some of these bills make literally no sense, right. One, the bill in Iowa bans the teaching, and I wrote it down. It bans the teaching of the following topics, sexism, slavery, racial segregation --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Well, it's in the bill. Did you read it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That is not true.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Did you read it?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I haven't read the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Okay then. Then you --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I would that -- no, I will tell you something. I will bet --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Then you don't know. Then you don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- you cannot find anything in the bill that says we will not teach slavery in school in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: It says it's prohibited. It says it's prohibited from the curriculum.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I guarantee. I guarantee you, Richard --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: It's prohibited from the curriculum. It's in section five of the bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- they have not prohibited the teaching of slavery in history class in the state of Iowa.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Well, allow me to finish.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I guarantee that's wrong.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Allow me to finish.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And I say that with no knowledge of the bill. No knowledge of the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Okay. Well, therein lies your problem.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Because if that actually was in the bill, it would have been on the front page of every newspaper in this country.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Well, it actually was in Iowa, but back to what I was saying.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Johnny, time to go.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: So the topics it currently blocks is sexism, slavery, racial segregation, racial discrimination including topics related to the enactment and the enforcement of laws resulting in sexism, racial oppression and segregation. That's like half of American history.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes, so you're saying history is banned.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: So back in history -- excuse me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: History is banned in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: So what that actually means is if you're a student, a high school student in Iowa and you're studying for the American AP history exam --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: -- you're likely to fail because half of these topics won't be taught. So, good luck to the students in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Okay. So they're just going to skip over --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And the bill in Oklahoma.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Basically from 1776, they're not teaching --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And the bill in Tennessee

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Well, after they can't teach -- they can't -- and actually --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- history, sports, in 1965 in Iowa. I don't believe that, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Actually, if you read the wording specific, they really couldn't teach 1976 because Abigail Adams' letters to her husband about remembering the women would actually be illegal, part of the bill in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, that's what I've said. They don't even start in 1776.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I was just telling you what the bill says which is part of the problem --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: History starts in Iowa in 1965 --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: -- which is part of the problem, because when you attack critical race theory and actually not talk about what's actually being taught in class which is the truth about American history we have this dilemma which is vaguely, poorly written, quickly written bills, that makes absolutely positively no sense.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We will find out the truth about the bill in Iowa and then we will tell you as soon as we find out.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Have fun reading them. I did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Coming up next, a bloody crime wave has the public terrified. And Biden's plan to fix it is to blame the last administration.

utterances.utterance: President Biden forced to confront a nationwide spike in violent crime but it looks to be too little too late. In New York City, a campaign volunteer was stabbed multiple times with an icepick. The president is set to finally address the carnage tomorrow but instead of focusing on restoring law and order, Biden will blame guns and the last administration.

utterances.utterance: There are major cities across the country where gun violence is absolutely the driver, where it is absolutely increasing and that will be a central part of what he'll talk about when he delivers his remarks tomorrow. There has been, one, an increase in violent crime over the last 18 months. It's not just over the last few months. And actually if you look statistically back, it's more over the last five years or so.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL

utterances.speaker: BRITTANY PACKNETT, ACTIVIST
utterances.utterance: There are a lot of police unions and GOP operatives that would like for us to believe that this recent crime wave has everything to do with this idea of defunding the police.
