utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know, gun violence isn't any more relevant than icepick violence, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's like, why don't we start talking about icepick violence because these are inanimate objects. It's interesting watching how the media and the democrats change the language so that it absolves the criminals. So what they are doing now is they're including gang shootings and routine gun crime that's been around as mass shootings, which mass shootings were always about these planned rampages, right? Now it's just every day, like CNN will say there were eight mass shootings this week and you go, wow, I didn't hear of any of them. And then you look at them, it's like, oh, you know, that's gang stuff. The problem with this stuff when they keep saying gun violence, and this is where their whole theory falls apart. The guns existed before and after this dramatic spike. So, it's not just gun violence. It's actually the perpetrators, a rise in perpetrators. A rise in violence. The gun is simply a tool. And when you explain these statistics plainly to the media, their response is after you saw what, I think with Stelter, Brian Stelter a few days ago, rather than acknowledge the spike in crime, the issue becomes are you blowing the spike in crime out of proportion? So whenever the media is found to be wrong on something, rather than admit it, they look at you and you go, but you're pouncing on it. You're blowing this out of proportion. Yes, yes, yes. I mean, there was crime -- there's crime, but you're blowing it out of proportion because the media cannot report on crime because it illustrates the failure of the far left policies that they have been pushing for decades and recently embraced in the last few years through the BLM movement. All of this stuff is falling apart before their eyes. And they'd rather see a country suffer than admit they were wrong and back the right course.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I was just thinking about President Biden having this event tomorrow. We talked yesterday about the polling numbers showing that crime and the issue of immigration are the two issues that are weighing down his approval ratings even though he is still up 52 percent where he had been at 57 or 58 percent. So, I think one of the reason they're having this event tomorrow is they know that they've got an issue so they're trying to shore themselves up politically. But if you remember, it was -- President Biden, when he was senator and the Clintons before him, their support of the 1994 Crime Bill was what the progressive left was hanging on their necks as an albatross. It was going to make it very hard for them to be able to get the votes of the left wing of the party. And so now, if they go forward tomorrow and they say, well now we're going to get tough on crime, I don't think he's going to say that. He would be, you know, called a traitor by the left and no one on the right would take him seriously.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: And he's going to talk about guns. And in New York City, you've seen all of the crimes that are up this year are murder, rape, felony assault, grand theft auto, housing crimes, other sex crimes, shooting victims, shooting incidents and hate crimes, but this is a city where the second amendment doesn't exist, Richard. So, how can you marry the two? Because he's going to talk about essentially hammering down law-abiding gun owners, not getting guns out of the hands of criminals because, again, they coddle criminals and they treat victims like garbage.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Well, a couple of things on that particular point. Number one, as a licensed gun owner myself, I don't think this is about taking the guns out of the hands of people like myself, but I think it's making sure that most of the crimes that we see happening that are gun crimes are because of folks have illegal guns. And I think we have to acknowledge that America is country that has poor supporters. So, if you have bad gun laws, say for example, in a bordering state, you can go over there, you can buy a gun and you can drive it across the border, right? And many of the guns that we see and many of the mass shootings that we see happening in this country sometimes happen because of illegal guns. In the city of Chicago, right, this past weekend was one of the most horrific weekends there and most of those crimes were committed because of illegal guns. Not purchased in the city of Chicago because you can't purchase a gun in the city of Chicago. They are purchased in Indiana and in other parts of the country that have terrible gun laws. So what Joe Biden is going to do tomorrow is say, hey, look, we've got to do something. Thoughts and prayers around the fact that we have a surge in gun violence in this country is not enough. Since the beginning of the year, we've had 283 mass shootings in this country. That's a 40 percent increase since last year and a 65 percent increase since 2019. So something has got to be done, right. And it can't just be --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You illustrated my point by saying mass shootings. You say these are all the -- what are these mass shootings?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: A mass shooting is any time more than three or more people are killed by a gun. And sadly, in the city of Chicago, it happens all the time and it's happening because of illegal guns.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's called -- that's gang violence.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Sure. Call it -- call it a gang violence, but even the police think that there's a problem with illegal guns.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But when you change it to mass shootings, you're blaming everything together so you can talk about the gun when you should be talking about the gangs and the criminals that are being let in and let out.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But even -- but (inaudible), even if you support police, even if you support police, if you talk to the police chiefs all across the country they will tell you one of the number one problems they face is the proliferation of illegal guns on their streets. So police agree that we've got to do something about the fact --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And also criminals going out and those guns somehow ending up back in their hands.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: This has been --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Sure. But why don't we get these guns off the streets to begin with by passing laws and make it harder for folks to get guns. Period.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: I want to hear Joe Biden talk about all the crimes outside of the gun crimes like elderly people getting punched in the face by somebody who has been arrested 20 times in the last couple of years. Why is that person on the street? I want to talk about just the quality of life crimes which are totally illegal here in New York City, so little children are walking down the street and having to witness sex acts in broad daylight, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm glad Richard --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That wasn't Jesse's fault.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm glad Richard is concerned about the poorest borders, just borders between states, not between countries. I'm glad you're consistent.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: No, let's not mix -- oh boy, here we go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Johnny has been hard at work looking at the Iowa bill. And Johnny reports the word slavery is not even in the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Listen, I read the bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: According to Johnny, they want to ban the 1619 Project --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: The 1619 project is not in the bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- which incorporates slavery --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: The 1619 Project --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- but they do not want to ban the teaching of slavery.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Listen, you can read an article, but I've actually read all of the bills.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's what we're reporting from the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: You can control fine because listen, let's be very clear.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're not talking about this anymore. I just reported what was not in the bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: You can't read a 10-page bill on a commercial break to be fair and to be clear. I read the bills --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You find if, until the audience -- you find it --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I already did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You spent the entire commercial break looking at your phone trying to find it.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: No, you sat the entire commercial break --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And you spent more minutes during the segment, trying to find it and you still haven't found it. Let me talk about something else.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: You, listen, Jesse, deal. Deal. Deal.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Yes, I'd let him talk.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: You and your producer spent the whole commercial break trying to read a bill that's (inaudible).

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I want to talk about something else. You still haven't actually pointed to the tact (ph).

utterances.speaker: MCDWOELL
utterances.utterance: I want to hear what he has to say.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let me just go full Gutfeld for a second, and going full Gutfeld that means you blame the media for everything. The mainstream media is lying about why black Americans are dying. The mainstream media back to defund the police movement. It gave license to these radical city councils to actually to defund the police. It triggers a crime wave. Black Americans got slaughtered in the streets and then you deny there was a crime wave. Now all of a sudden they are waking up to the fact that there is a crime wave and they're heaping praise on Joe Biden for tackling the crime wave they help to create. The "Washington Post," because you know I read these briefing materials for these segments very carefully, they actually did a whole story on this. They quoted an aid to Michael Dukakis. Michael Dukakis said there is nothing the federal government can do about crime because it's a local issue. It's the same Michael Dukakis that got rocked by 41 by being soft on crime. Then they quoted three anti-police activists in the article. No balance at all, and it leads the reader to believe it's the fault of the Republicans for the rise in crime because blah, blah, blah, NRA. They didn't spend one minute interviewing a black crime victim. They didn't interview any family members who had their family members shot. They didn't interview anybody scared that's living in the inner-city that is afraid to go to school. All they care about is the political effects on the Democrats and if it's risky or if it's safe for the Democrats. No, no, no. This is about life and death in the inner-city and the media doesn't care about it.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: They will focus group and poll the subject to death while there is actual deaths in the streets.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: Ahead, some serious media bias. The "Washington Post" giving Democrats cover after a major flip-flop.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The "Washington Post" getting slammed over a report on Democrats changing stance on voter I.D. laws. The headline reading this, "Stacey Abrams and the Democrats' Evolution on Voter I.D." The former gubernatorial candidate now says she could back voter I.D. which comes just two months after she compared the requirements to Jim Crow. Other Democrats have been bashing Republican-backed voting laws.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY)
utterances.utterance: Making it harder for younger, poorer, non-white and typically Democratic voters to have -- to access the ballot. Shame, shame, shame.

utterances.speaker: SEN. MAZIE HIRONO (D-HI)
utterances.utterance: This is why when the states start to enact these kinds of voter suppression laws, what I call steal your vote laws.

utterances.speaker: SEN. BERNIE SANDERS (I-VT)
utterances.utterance: -- is to try to deny people of color, young people, poor people the right to vote, people with disabilities.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, when Senator Manchin of West Virginia came out, Greg, with his compromise bill. He said, here we go. I'll have voter ID. And Stacey Abrams from Georgia said, I like it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But she has this Web site called Jim Crow 2.0 and she still lists voter ID, that provision as voter suppression.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think that -- this is what happens when you overplay the race card because what happens is, there's no workable solution. Like if you constantly keep saying everything is racist, there's nothing left. They don't -- they're not even sure -- the Democrat Party isn't even sure what they're talking about. Years from now, people are going to look back at this era, especially what Chuck Schumer did in the Democratic Party as the real racist, the white liberal supremacist for assuming that blacks can't get an ID. Think about the contradiction between that message and the message of diversity which is positive. Hey, black people, you can be an astronaut, you can be an engineer, you can be a rocket scientist, but you can't get an ID, because that's beyond your abilities. It is the same -- it's the same mentality that is behind critical race theory which is white supremacy for liberal elites. It's an academic restatement that blacks aren't capable and only superior whites, superior whites to blacks can help them. That is why it is so disgusting.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A couple of the other issues that are in this bill are provisions, Dagen, include a proposal to divert taxpayer money to pay for campaigns. That's really, really unpopular. And then, also a mandate for ballot trafficking, which basically says you can go around and pick up the bills - - or pick up the ballots and take them to your local precinct.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: They're federalizing election law and they're taking power away from the states. And I think everybody should be upset about that. And to kind of paraphrase something that Senator Tom Cotton said, he said, the Democrats, if you listen to those comments, they're not defending their own H.R.1 or the voting bill. They're attacking Republicans because they know that they can't stand on the merits of this bill. And I do love -- it's what Greg was talking about in the last -- in the last segment, but I do love how democrats evolve and soften their positions in the words of the media, but Republicans cave and flip flop. Because that's how -- that's how they frame it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's -- those are verbs that they use. Richard, the Honest Elections Project, they did a poll on this bill. And it turns out that only 29 percent of people actually have any idea what's in it.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Listen, people don't read bills.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Stop right there.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But I do think what's interesting is in the Joe -- in the -- in the Joe Manchin compromise, right, which is the first amendment that would be taken up if there was allowed to be a debate, which there won't because Republicans will block it, is actually some things that I think are bipartisan in nature, which is what Joe Biden committed to being, right? He said, the Republicans' biggest sticking point was voter ID. Democrats said we're willing to give on voter ID in exchange for expanding -- expansions of early voting, banning partisan redistricting, which I think everybody agrees with. If you're a Republican in New York, you probably are against partisan redistricting. Or if you're a Republican in Illinois, you're probably against partisan redistricting, right? And also making Election Day holiday, which I think most folks agree with. If you can make Election Day holiday, everybody will have the ability to vote.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Another holiday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I'm all for it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And we have to work.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: We will always -- we work because we were in the media.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We'll tape a holiday special, fan mail.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But I do think that this is what you call meeting in the middle, right? There is -- there's a lot of provisions in the Joe -- in the Joe Manchin compromised of what was in the 1965 civil rights -- Voting Rights Act, bring in those across in exchange for voter ID which something that Republicans have been asking for very long time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But I mean, Jesse, there were a couple of issues I just mentioned, taxpayer money for campaigns, ballot trafficking, and a few others.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's not a compromise. It's called a poison pill. Fox News Alert, I was right. Richard was wrong.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The definitive answer is that Iowa Republicans did not, I repeat, did not submit a bill banning the teaching of slavery in schools in Iowa.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Where did they ban the teaching of slavery? Where did they -- did they not ban the teaching of slavery?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Fox News Alert, it's over.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Did they not ban the teaching of slavery?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: This was about some curriculum involving --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Did they not ban -- they ban the --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- diversity training in companies. That was wrong. I was right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Excuse me. So, the bill --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I was right.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: -- to be clear and to be fair --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Go ahead, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: The bill bans the teaching, and let me go back to my notes, of slavery, sexism, racial segregation, and racial discrimination --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Where, Richard? Where, Richard.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: In training for employees and students --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, OK, so not in schools.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: In a school setting.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Where else would they be --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's not what you said. That's not what you said, Richard.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the funniest thing ever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Teaching slavery is not prohibited in Iowa in this bill.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Not to mention the fact -- not to mention the fact that the bill is poor -- it's poorly written, it is vague --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Poorly read too.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: It has no -- it has no enforcement criteria, and it bans the ideal of teaching slavery and --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Just take the shake.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just take the L.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: There's none to be taken.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Just take the L, Richard. I'm extending a hand.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: We'll shake, but there's no -- the fact is that it's a poorly written bill and you know it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Listen, all bills are poorly written. I agree with that.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: You should read them more.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: We're killing it -- we're killing it with the Iowa demo.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, up next, shameful and grifty, a former Obama ethics chief plays into hunter Biden's art career.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There reviews are in for Hunter's art career. Former Obama White House ethics chief is tearing into the First Son's plan to sell his paintings for prices up to a half million. That's one of them. "The notion of a president son capitalizing on that relationship by selling art at obviously inflated prices and keeping the public in the dark about who's funneling money to him has a shameful and grifty feel to it." And Hunter is not the only member -- family member cashing in. Relatives of key White House officials have landed jobs in the administration. But Jen Psaki says there's nothing to worry about.

utterances.speaker: JEN PSAKI, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: We have the highest ethical standards of any administration in history. A number of ethics officials have conveyed that and we're proud of that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana, could you argue that Hunter's paintings are designed to keep his nose clean. Because that's why he uses straws, he get paint in it and they can't put it up your nose.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I mean, that could be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It might be a part of you know --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's how you beat your habit, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I loved doing blow art.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I did as a kid. That was one of the best things that Vacation Bible School we would do that. It's fun.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Vacation Bible School.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What's vacation Bible School?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I went to Vacation Bible School.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You went to --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: I do too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wait, wait, wait --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We're the weirdos here, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We didn't go to the Vacation Bible School.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, in the summertime, it's sometimes Christmas holiday or Easter holiday --

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Yes, I went to VBS.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- there's a week where you go to like a camp every day. It's Vacation Bible School. And you get to do like crafts and activities like blow art.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: And learn about Jesus.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And learn the Beatitudes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe we should have gone to that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. I think -- I think there's a hole in my life.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Vacation Bible School was awesome. The last thing I'll say on this is responding indignantly to questions about ethics in regards to the President's son or, you know, other situations, is kind of ironic given that they really ran against President Trump based on his ethics --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and their perceived view of ethics.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How quickly they forget, Dana. How quickly they forgot. Dagen, you know, what's wrong with selling art based on your notoriety? It's not just kind of like an autograph?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: No. If your father is in the White House and you have a history of questionable at the very least behavior. A year and a half ago, nobody even knew this loser was an artist until the New York Times wrote this glowing profile of him just as the pandemic was taking off, but they won't appeal it for the Coronavirus coverage. There's a new artist in town, the name is Biden was the title of it. And they talk about oh the paint-stained forearms and fingers and the black and red deep under his nails. So, now he's selling these things are trying to for half a million dollars. I'd say that -- of that price, 90 percent is bribery, maybe 10 percent is for the paint, but nobody now is going to buy this dreck because they're going to have their background looked into. Like, you're going to get a ring-a-ding-ding from the FBI or Justice.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, maybe he slips coke into the canvas. That's a great way to get it over the porous border. Richard, the one thing about nepotism, I think that we could agree on, is that it hurts minorities because we have - - you're already laughing at my question?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: How did minority get into this?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because white people have the jobs that they can just hire their cronies' kids.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I thought we're talking about Hunter Biden?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, we're talking about nepotism.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Well, listen, I --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Minorities are hurt most by nepotism because they aren't in the power structure to give the jobs to their kids and friends.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Fair, fair enough.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think that's in the bill in the Iowa bill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Fair enough. Look, I think that -- you know, I don't think the Hunter should be selling his paintings. And listen, I also think that in this particular one, as we talked about Hunter Biden, it's worth pointing out that there's still a pending justice investigation that is going unharmed, untouched by the Merrick Garland Justice Department against Hunter Biden, which speaks to the fact that this -- that Joe Biden, he believes in this ideal of an independent justice system and a Justice Department and that's -- and that's happening. With that being said, it's also worth pointing out that there's no Biden people that work in the White House unlike the Trump White House where everybody who work --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But their point was that though, that there are -- there are few people who are couples that are appointed in the White House.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: True.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That often happens. You meet in Washington and you stay in Washington, you know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's the swamp, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Nobody wanted to hire Peter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When I coined the phrase swamp, that's what I was talking about. We need to drain that swamp. Jesse, I don't know if selling art is a bad thing because I have a feeling you and I are going to be doing this very -- in the next 10 years.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: We're going to be doing blow art?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, or blow art, yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Or Vacation Bible School.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We should probably do both.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: One before the other. So, do you consider me a petty person, Gutfeld?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Perhaps.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Would you mind if I acted a little petty?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh, please do.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Last week, I said on this very show that Hunter selling his little blow art to, I don't know, a Russian billionaire for a half a mil was violating the spirit of campaign finance and potential, I don't know, laundering laws, bribery statutes, whatever. Now, did that make waves? No. Then the ethics expert for Joe Biden says it and everyone goes, oh, really? Well, perhaps we should look into this. It doesn't take an expert to realize this is a scam.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do I need a new title?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is Fox Host not enough for people to pay attention?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: You need to be an ethics expert.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, do I have to do law school for people to listen to me? It's clearly a scam. Why does an expert have to tell you, and then everybody says, oh yeah, it's a scam? I said it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When you look at -- look at those paintings. Just look at those paintings you realize that it looks like, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: I don't know why you'd spend $1 million on that though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What does it look like to you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, I was waiting for him to throw one up there, but it just looks like --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: What does that -- like --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It looks like a leftover from a smurf orgy.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: But why would you spend $1 million on that? I just don't understand.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, that's what it is. It's --

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: That's the point, Richard.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, you don't understand, Richard.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: It's influence meddling.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, "THE FASTEST" is up.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, boy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We got time for "THE FASTEST."

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Welcome back. It's time for "THE FASTEST." Researchers are coming up with a special straw device that will -- that promises to cure the hiccups 90 percent of the time. It will cost about $14.00. So, Dagen, would you buy it?

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: No, I like being frightened --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I was going to say the opposite. I hate it.

utterances.speaker: MCDOWELL
utterances.utterance: To cure -- to cure -- like, if you come up just a little -- if you come up behind me and make the sound of the doll from trilogy of terror, like that will cure hiccups anytime. And I actually enjoyed that.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Jesse?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Classic.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Hiccups are for drunks and babies. I don't think researchers should be focused on this. I'd like to cure cancer. We could focus on hiccups later.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Hiccups is a very serious condition for some people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It is -- well, maybe I shouldn't say that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I read the bill.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I preferred my mom's method which is a teaspoon of sugar. It was apparently supposed to help you -- like, I don't know.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, that's the medicine goes down.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I know, but -- well, I don't know. That's what she thought would cure hiccups too.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Maybe in Bible camp.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You have to try it.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: If one of my kids had hiccups, they'd be out the door.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Would you try the straw though?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: Would you buy the straw?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, because you have to weigh the incidence, the number of times you have hiccups versus the cost of carrying a product around. How many times you got the hiccups? Once every two years. I tried to go back through my head the last time I had hiccups, I can't remember. So, you actually don't really need a product unless you're one of these persistent hiccupers.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, you have a purse. You put it in the purse.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Purse, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And that's how you carry it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You carry a gun in your purse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I know I didn't have a purse, Dana. I carry --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's called man bag.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's a man bag, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a man bag.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Fanny pack.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Fanny pack.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No, I don't have a fanny pack.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: When you're walking Jesse Jr. around the park.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Stop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Do you have a little front bag for your baby?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You mean a baby bjorn?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A baby bjorn.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I have but I haven't rocked it yet.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You haven't rocked it? God helped me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I haven't rocked the bjorn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: God help me.

utterances.speaker: FOWLER
utterances.utterance: All right, "ONE MORE THING" is up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "ONE MORE THING." So, yesterday, I was off. The ratings were particularly good, so that was a little disturbing, but I'm OK with it. I had the honor to play in the 30th annual Van Fleet Memorial Golf Tournament at Baltusrol in New Jersey hosted by the Korea Society. It helps foster good relationship between the United States and Korea. You know, James Van Fleet was the commanding general of the U.S. Army during the Korean War and we're very grateful for him. Also to Mike Woods who co-chaired the event, Big Sun Holdings right there. And special shout out to the boys Friends Academy Lacrosse team won the Long Island State Championship, 15-14 in OT, beat Port Jefferson for the title. Congrats, guys. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, so I read a book this weekend and it was Jesse's book.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I have to tell you, I read it in one day. I loved it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Cover to cover, very funny, very smart.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Very well-written. I thought the page-turner. I'm going to -- if it's OK, I'm going to do this something that you did. I am -- John gave me permission to read one of the little mom text thing.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, when you get the book and everybody should, you're going to be very tempted not to skip ahead to the end, you're going to skip ahead to the How I Saved My Mom's text chapter. That's the -- that's the sweet stuff, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I appear in this a couple of times a couple.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A couple.
